title: IoT Conceptual Framework
content: - Analyzes and determines smart activities of intelligent devices.
Maintains dynamic interconnection among devices.
Standardizes IoT infrastructure for e-services based on context information.
Enables collaboration among heterogeneous devices and protocols.
Utilizes cloud computing for ambient computing.
Logically divides physical device placement.
Creates virtual links among different domains and networks.
Collaborates among multiple applications without central coordination.
Leverages IaaS for standard functionalities and access to cloud infrastructure.
image_desc: A diagram depicting the four layers of the IoT conceptual framework, with arrows showing data flow between layers.
narration: This slide introduces the IoT conceptual framework, which aims to analyze and manage the interactions of intelligent devices. It emphasizes the importance of standardization, collaboration, and cloud computing for achieving ambient computing. The framework is designed to be flexible and scalable, allowing for the integration of diverse devices and applications without requiring a central control system.

title: Connectivity Layer
content: - Includes all physical devices and their interconnections.
Unifies common objects for identification and control.
Assigns low-range networking devices (sensors, actuators, RFID tags).
Manages resources to ensure maximum utilization with minimal overhead.
Shares and distributes information among multiple networks or domains.
image_desc: A close-up view of a network of sensors, actuators, and RFID tags connected to a gateway.
narration: The Connectivity Layer forms the foundation of the framework, encompassing all physical devices and their connections. It focuses on unifying common objects, managing resources efficiently, and enabling information sharing across networks. This layer ensures that devices can be identified and controlled, paving the way for seamless integration and communication.

title: Access Layer
content: - Collects raw data from short-range devices through IoT gateways.
Defines topology, initiates networks, and creates domains.
Handles connection setup, intra-inter domain communication, scheduling, and packet transmissions.
Includes feature management with a filter for accepting only relevant context data.
Reduces irrelevant data transmission, increases data transfer rate, and minimizes energy and CPU consumption.
image_desc: A diagram showing data flowing from sensors to an IoT gateway, then to the Access Layer, where it is filtered and processed.
narration: The Access Layer acts as a bridge between the physical devices and the internet. It collects raw data from sensors and other devices, processes it, and prepares it for transmission to higher layers. Feature management plays a crucial role in filtering out irrelevant data, optimizing data transfer rates, and conserving energy resources.

title: Abstraction Layer
content: - Adds virtual layers to the existing infrastructure without altering it.
Creates virtual links among different networks, enabling a common platform for various communication systems.
Provides a centralized system for monitoring and controlling traffic.
Improves bandwidth, reliability, routing, and overall Quality of Service (QoS).
Addresses multi-hopping scenarios by creating virtual links between sensor networks, reducing load on access points and enhancing network resilience.
image_desc: A diagram showing a virtual network overlaying a physical network, with virtual links connecting different physical networks.
narration: The Abstraction Layer introduces virtualization, allowing for the creation of virtual networks and links on top of the existing physical infrastructure. This layer enables centralized monitoring and control, improving network performance and resilience. It also addresses challenges associated with multi-hopping scenarios, ensuring efficient data transmission even in complex network environments.

title: Service Layer
content: - Manages storage, security, and access to data.
Integrates data to enhance service intelligence and analysis.
Increases storage efficiency.
Includes data storage, system supervision, software services, business management, and operations.
Combines required services with organizational solutions, simplifying user experience.
Supports emerging services related to environment analysis, safety measurement, climate management, and agriculture modernization.
image_desc: A diagram showing data being stored, analyzed, and used to deliver services, with cloud computing and business management systems integrated.
narration: The Service Layer focuses on data management, security, and service delivery. It ensures efficient storage, access, and integration of data, enabling intelligent services and analysis. This layer also incorporates business management and operations, ensuring the smooth functioning of the entire system and supporting the development of new services that address societal needs.
